title: Mediterranean Diet
shortSummary: TODO: The Mediterranean diet emphasizes olive oil, fresh vegetables, fruits, legumes, whole grains, and fish consumption, supporting heart health as a traditional nutritional approach. (200-300 characters)
whoItsFor: TODO: Those who want to protect heart health
TODO: Those who want to lose weight healthily and sustainably
TODO: Those who want to control cholesterol and blood pressure levels
TODO: Those who want to support brain health
TODO: Those who don't want to give up delicious and varied meals

cautions.warning: TODO: Consult your doctor for some vegetables high in potassium.
TODO: Determine olive oil amount with your doctor.
TODO: Consider alternatives if you have seafood, gluten, or nut allergies.

corePrinciples: TODO: Consume plenty of vegetables at every meal
TODO: Use olive oil as the main fat source
TODO: Eat fish at least twice a week
TODO: Limit red meat consumption to a few portions per month
TODO: Add legumes several times a week
TODO: Snack on small amounts of nuts
TODO: Stay away from processed foods
TODO: Share meals with loved ones

dailyTargets.note: TODO: Half of the plate should be vegetables at every meal
TODO: Prefer fruit instead of dessert
TODO: Whole grains instead of refined grains
TODO: Main beverage should be water

weeklyTargets.note: TODO: Prefer fish rich in omega-3
TODO: Limit to a few times per month

breakfast.name: TODO: Mediterranean Breakfast
breakfast.description: TODO: Whole grain bread, olive oil, tomatoes, cucumbers, white cheese, olives, and freshly squeezed orange juice

lunch.name: TODO: Grilled Fish Plate
lunch.description: TODO: Olive oil sea bass, bulgur pilaf, seasonal salad, and lemon sauce

dinner.name: TODO: Vegetable Lentil Soup
dinner.description: TODO: Lentil soup, whole wheat bread, and olive oil artichoke

snacks.name: TODO: Snack 1
snacks.description: TODO: A handful of almonds and fresh fruit

snacks.name: TODO: Snack 2
snacks.description: TODO: Hummus with carrot and celery sticks

tips: TODO: Add olive oil to every meal but control the amount
TODO: Make eating fish at least 2-3 times a week a habit
TODO: Prefer seasonal fruit instead of dessert
TODO: Sharing meals with family or friends increases satiety
TODO: Prefer seasonal and locally produced products
TODO: Eat slowly and chew each bite thoroughly
commonMistakes: TODO: Consuming olive oil excessively - it's a calorie-dense fat
TODO: Thinking you're doing the 'Mediterranean' diet by only eating pasta and bread
TODO: Constantly choosing red meat instead of fish
TODO: Mistaking processed olive oil products for extra virgin olive oil
TODO: Overusing wine (not recommended, water is preferred)

faq.question: TODO: Can I eat meat on the Mediterranean diet?
faq.answer: TODO: Yes, but red meat should be limited to a few portions per month. Fish and poultry are preferred.

faq.question: TODO: Can I use another oil instead of olive oil?
faq.answer: TODO: Olive oil is the foundation of the Mediterranean diet. Avocado oil can be considered as an alternative.

faq.question: TODO: Is this diet expensive?
faq.answer: TODO: It can be economical when seasonal and local products are preferred. Legumes are an inexpensive protein source.

faq.question: TODO: Can I follow this as a vegetarian?
faq.answer: TODO: Yes, you can meet your protein needs with legumes, tofu, and eggs instead of fish.

faq.question: TODO: How long until I see results?
faq.answer: TODO: This is a lifestyle. Energy increase can be seen within a few weeks, weight and blood values improvement within a few months.
